true.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: based on facts and not imagined or invented
true.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: No, honestly, it’s a true story.
Students decide if statements are true or false.
It’s generally true to say that fewer people are needed nowadays.
The results appear to hold true (=still be correct) for other countries.
It’s not true that I’m going to marry him.
The same is true of all political parties.
This is especially true for old people.
true.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the true nature of something is its real nature, which may be hidden or not known
true.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We need to understand the true extent of the problem.
She managed to conceal her true feelings.
After a couple of days she showed her true self (=real character).
The house was sold for only a fraction of its true value.
She wasn’t aware of the true nature of their relationship.
true.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: used when you are admitting that something is correct, but saying that something else, often opposite, is also correct
true.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: ‘He’s very hard-working.’ ‘True, but I still don’t think he’s the right man for the job.’
It is true that there have been improvements in some areas.
true.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: having all the qualities which a type of thing or person should have
true.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The heroine finally finds true love.
She’s been a true friend to me.
It’s an amateur sport in the true sense of the word (=with the exact meaning of this word).
true.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: faithful and loyal to someone, whatever happens
true.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Throughout the whole ordeal, she remained true to her husband.
true.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: fitted, placed, or formed in a way that is perfectly flat, straight, correct etc
true.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: If the door’s not true, it won’t close properly.
true.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: The prisoners are encouraged to confront the true nature of their crimes.
At the time, I did not recognise the true value of my discovery.
The fixed prescription charge conceals from the general public the true cost of medicines.
Our main difficulty is finding out the true extent of the problem.
The story teaches a lesson about the true meaning of friendship.
He knew someone would soon discover his true identity.
Stephen’s controlled voice disguised his true feelings.
He had revealed his true self.
true.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: true
based on real facts, and not imagined or invented
The film was based on a true story.
Do you think the rumours are true?
based on facts and not containing any mistakes – used about descriptions, information, and numbers
The measurements are accurate.
His assessment of the current economic situation is accurate.
undeniable/indisputable
definitely true, so that no one can argue or disagree about it
It is indisputable that the situation has got worse.
The decline in inflation was undeniable, even if the reasons for the decline were unclear.
factual
based on facts, or involving facts
The court makes its decision based on factual evidence.
There is very little factual information about the incident.
a factual account of what happened
The questions ask for a purely factual answer, not for opinion.
verifiable
able to be proven to be true or correct
The data was verifiable.
it is a fact
used when saying that something is definitely true
It is a fact that women live longer than men.
be the truth
to be true – used when saying that someone is not lying
What I told you was the truth.
be the case
if a situation is the case, that is the way the situation truly is
It is certainly the case that crime rates are lower in Europe than in the US.
true.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The arrow flew straight and true to its target.
true.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if a type of animal breeds true, the young animals are exactly like their parents
true.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: used to describe the actual amount of something, when extra hidden amounts are added to or taken from it
true.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The APR is the annual percentage rate of the total charge for credit or the true cost of borrowing.
